6. TERMS OF PAYMENT
6.1 Payment Terms. JRVS shall submit an invoice to the Distributor upon shipment of Products to the Distributor. The
invoice shall state the amount to be paid by the Distributor for all Products in such shipment, as well as any taxes, duties or
excises paid by JRVS which shall be reimbursed by the Distributor in accordance with Section 5.4. Terms of payment shall be net
thirty (30) days. All payments shall be in U.S. Dollars.
perturbation.changed_text:
6. TERMS OF PAYMENT
6.1 Payment Terms. JRVS shall submit an invoice to the Distributor upon shipment of Products to the Distributor. The
invoice shall state the amount to be paid by the Distributor for all Products in such shipment, as well as any taxes, duties or
excises paid by JRVS which shall be reimbursed by the Distributor in accordance with Section 5.4. Terms of payment shall be net
forty-five (45) days. All payments shall be in U.S. Dollars.
perturbation.explanation: In the United States, while there's no federal law mandating specific payment terms between businesses, unreasonably long payment terms (like 45 days) can be deemed unfair, especially for smaller distributors. This can run afoul of state-level prompt payment laws or be viewed as an unconscionable contract provision, creating a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Prompt Payment Laws, Unconscionability Doctrine under contract law

perturbation.original_text:
7.2 Inspection and Acceptance. The Distributor shall have thirty (30) days (the “Inspection Period”) upon receipt of each
shipment to inspect and test the Products. If the Distributor determines any unit of Products defective, the Distributor shall
promptly notify JRVS of such defects. Defective Products may be returned for retest, evaluation and examination subject to JRVS
Returned Material Authorization (“RMA”) procedure; provided, that such written notification and request for an RMA number
must be received by JRVS during the Inspection Period. Returns must be prepaid by Distributor. When requesting a return
authorization, Distributor must supply Distributor’s purchase order number and JRVS’s invoice number. Product description must
include lot number and wafer numbers.
perturbation.changed_text:
7.2 Inspection and Acceptance. The Distributor shall have ten (10) days (the “Inspection Period”) upon receipt of each
shipment to inspect and test the Products. If the Distributor determines any unit of Products defective, the Distributor shall
promptly notify JRVS of such defects. Defective Products may be returned for retest, evaluation and examination subject to JRVS
Returned Material Authorization (“RMA”) procedure; provided, that such written notification and request for an RMA number
must be received by JRVS during the Inspection Period. Returns must be prepaid by Distributor. When requesting a return
authorization, Distributor must supply Distributor’s purchase order number and JRVS’s invoice number. Product description must
include lot number and wafer numbers.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the inspection period to 10 days is very short. If the distributor needs longer to test all the units, this could contradict implied warranty laws or general fairness principles, particularly if defects aren't immediately apparent. This could be argued as an unconscionable or unreasonable limitation on the distributor's ability to identify and address defects.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Warranty of Merchantability, UCC § 2-606, Unconscionability under contract law

13.2 Limitation on Actions. NO ACTIONS, REGARDLESS OF FORM, ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT, MAY BE
BROUGHT BY DISTRIBUTOR MORE THAN ONE (1) YEAR AFTER THE CAUSE OF ACTION HAS ARISEN.
perturbation.changed_text:
13.2 Limitation on Actions. NO ACTIONS, REGARDLESS OF FORM, ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT, MAY BE
BROUGHT BY DISTRIBUTOR MORE THAN SIX (6) MONTHS AFTER THE CAUSE OF ACTION HAS ARISEN.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the statute of limitations for bringing actions to 6 months from the standard limitations periods for contract disputes (which can be several years, depending on the jurisdiction and type of claim) could be deemed unconscionable and legally questionable. A shorter period severely limits the distributor's ability to pursue legal remedies if issues arise.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Statute of Limitations for Contract Claims (varies by state, typically longer than 6 months), Unconscionability under contract law
